name: Planning & Scoping
rationale:
Initially, the risk assessor and manager (and the 
planning team) need to evaluate and select the kind 
of risk information, exposure scenarios and 
assessment issues that need to be covered. At this 
point, most EPA assessments focus on technical 
information related to the sources, effects, 
populations and the routes of exposure.

name: Problem Formulation
rationale:
Problem formulation is a systematic approach that 
identifes all factors critical to a specifc risk 
assessment and considers the purpose of the 
assessment, scope and depth of the necessary 
analysis, analytical approach, available resources and 
outcomes, and overall risk management goal.

name: Analysis
rationale:
Two components of the analysis phase are exposure and effects 
assessments. In the exposure assessment, the risk assessor determines 
which plants and animals are or are likely to be exposed to each 
environmental stressor and to what degree. In the effects assessment, 
the risk assessor reviews available research on the relationship between 
exposure level and possible adverse effects on plants and animals. They 
may also review evidence of existing harmful ecological effects.

name: Risk Characterization
rationale:
Risk characterization includes two major componentsâ€”risk estimation and 
risk description. "Risk estimation" compares: the estimated or measured 
exposure level for each stressor and plant or animal population, community, 
or ecosystem of concern; and the data on expected effects for that group for 
the exposure level. "Risk description" provides information important for 
interpreting the risk results. This includes: whether harmful effects are 
expected on the plants and animals of concern; relevant qualitative 
comparisons; and how uncertainties (data gaps and natural variation) might 
affect the assessment.

name: Risk Communication
rationale:
Information from ecological risk assessments can be 
used by risk managers to: communicate with 
interested parties and the general public; limit 
exposure to the ecological stressor; negotiate 
remediation options with stakeholders; or develop 
monitoring plans to confrm risk reduction and 
ecosystem recovery.

name: Site Assessment
rationale:
A site assessment focuses on evaluating the 
potential risk of a release of hazardous substances 
or threat to people and the environment. Preliminary
determinations are made regarding need for 
immediate or further actions required. Background 
historical investigation information is collected.

name: Site Investigation and Alternatives Evaluation
rationale:
More integrated and in-depth site 
characterizations are made (e.g., Remedial 
Investigation/Feasibility Study [CERCLA], Phase II 
Environmental Site Assessments [Brownfeld], 
Facility Investigations [RCRA]. Remediation 
alternatives are evaluated.

name: Remedy Selection
rationale:
Formal selection of remedies for 
cleanup are defned in this stage (e.g., 
Record of Decision [CERCLA], Remedial 
Action Plan [Brownfeld], Statement of 
Basis [RCRA]).

name: Remedy Implementation
rationale:
Formal implementation of remedies for 
cleanup are defned in this stage (e.g., 
Remedial Design/Remedial Action [CERCLA], 
Cleanup and Development phase [Brownfeld], 
Corrective Measures Implementation [RCRA]).

name: Post-Construction Activities
rationale:
Operation and Maintenance phase. Also includes 
monitoring, inspections, and assessment for 
remedy effectiveness determinations, and 
adaptive management needs (e.g., remedy 
Optimization [CERCLA]). For Brownfelds, 
redevelopment activities may occur.

name: Clarify Decision Context
rationale:
Clearly articulating the question or issue being addressed. This includes
who should be involved in the decision making process and what types 
of options are being considered (but not getting into details about those
options). For example, if the issue was needing to fnd a place to live, 
you would identify all of those who would be living in the new place and 
whether renting and/or buying options should be considered.

name: Defne Objectives
rationale:
Clearly defning what matters when making the decision. This 
includes identifying the criteria that will be used in evaluating your 
options and agreed upon metrics for those evaluations. For 
example, one criterion when looking for a place to live would be 
price and that could be measured in dollars or as a percentage of 
your monthly take-home salary. Another criterion could be distance
from work and that could be measured in minutes or miles.

name: Defne Objectives
rationale:
Identifying the set of options to be evaluated. 
This includes looking at the full set of options 
that should be evaluated. For example, 
identifying the homes available for both rent and 
purchase in your desired neighborhood.

name: Estimate Consequences
rationale:
Examining how well each of the options fares in 
meeting the decision criteria identifed in step 
two. This includes measuring how well each 
option does on the criteria metrics identifed in 
the previous step. For example, identifying the 
rent or mortgage costs and driving time to work 
associated with each home.

name: Evaluate Trade-offs and Select
rationale:
Selecting the option that best meets your objectives. This 
includes evaluating the relative importance of those decision 
criteria. For example, if both price and distance to work are 
equally important, you may select a home that does reasonably
well on both metrics. If, however, commute is of more 
importance, you may select a signifcantly more expensive 
home in order to have the shortest possible commute.

name: Implement, Monitor, and Review
rationale:
Evaluating the decision after it has been made. This 
includes refecting on the process, the criteria, and the 
effcacy of the chosen option. For example, after 
choosing an apartment to rent, you may realize that 
you selected a home in a noisy neighborhood and 
recognize that, on your next home hunt, information 
about the neighborhood would be a useful criterion to 
include.
